name: Union City
fun_fact: Fun fact: Union City is the unofficial Filipino food capital of the Bay Areaâ€”Jollibee and Red Ribbon both opened here before expanding elsewhere, and it has more authentic Filipino restaurants per capita than anywhere outside the Philippines.

hero_dishes.name: Kare-Kare at Nayong Filipino
hero_dishes.description: Rich peanut-based oxtail stew with eggplant and bok choy, served with shrimp pasteâ€”velvety, savory, and deeply comforting
hero_dishes.origin_story: Nayong Filipino has been serving authentic family recipes since 2003, bringing the flavors of the Philippines to Bay Area families. Kare-kare represents hours of slow-cooking and generations of technique
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Nayong Filipino (1796 Whipple Rd)â€”a neighborhood institution since 2003

hero_dishes.name: Lechon at Tribu Grill
hero_dishes.description: Crispy-skinned roasted whole pig with impossibly tender meat, served with liver sauceâ€”the centerpiece of every Filipino celebration
hero_dishes.origin_story: Tribu Grill brings the fiesta tradition to everyday dining. Lechon was once reserved for special occasions, but here you can experience it any day of the week
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Tribu Grillâ€”known for generous portions and complimentary chicharon with every order

hero_dishes.name: Pancit Palabok
hero_dishes.description: Rice noodles topped with shrimp sauce, crushed chicharon, boiled eggs, and tinapa flakesâ€”a textural wonderland of crispy, soft, and savory
hero_dishes.origin_story: This festive noodle dish evolved from Chinese influence but became distinctly Filipino. In Union City, Filipino families have perfected recipes passed down through church festivals and home kitchens
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Nayong Filipino, Manila Turo Turo, or Isla Restaurant

hero_dishes.name: Halo-Halo
hero_dishes.description: The ultimate Filipino dessertâ€”shaved ice with ube ice cream, sweet beans, jellies, leche flan, and ube truffles piled high in a glass
hero_dishes.origin_story: At Cafe 86, the Southern California chain brings ube-obsessed modern Filipino sweets to the Bay. Their upside-down halo-halo is engineered for Instagram and maximum ube flavor
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Cafe 86 (34391 Alvarado-Niles Rd) or Red Ribbon for classic Filipino bakery sweets

signature_drinks.name: Calamansi Juice
signature_drinks.description: Refreshingly tart citrus drink made from tiny Filipino limesâ€”like lemonade with a tropical twist
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Served ice-cold with meals to cut through rich dishes like lechon and kare-kare. Street vendors and restaurants always have it fresh-squeezed

signature_drinks.name: San Miguel Beer
signature_drinks.description: The iconic Filipino lager that pairs perfectly with crispy pork and spicy vinegar dips
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Ice-cold bottles shared family-style at Tribu Grill or Gerry's Grill (the only Bay Area location of the massive Philippine chain)

food_culture_notes: Union City's Filipino food scene evolved from church festivals in the 1980s where families sold homemade lumpia by the thousands
The East Bay Filipino community makes Union City the destination for authentic regional Filipino foodâ€”not just Manila style
Jollibee's Chickenjoy fried chicken has a cult following among Filipino Americans who grew up with it
Complimentary chicharon and bagoong rice at Tribu Grill show the generosity of Filipino hospitality
